item.title: Could Google Lose Chrome in Antitrust Battle?
item.description:
Google and the US Department of Justice offer closing arguments Friday in the remedy phase of a trial over the tech giant's search monopolization. It's just one in a string of cases that have loomed over large tech firms this year as antitrust pressure mounts.
The DOJ has pushed for Google to spin off Chrome, but Google has fought back. Meanwhile, Apple, Meta and others are finding themselves targeted on both sides of the Atlantic.
Bloomberg's Charlie Wells reports. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Futures Slide as Tariff Concerns Sap Confidence: Markets Wrap
item.description: US stock futures fell as traders navigated renewed uncertainty about President Donald Trump’s tariff policies and their impact on the American economy.
item.dc:creator: Andre Janse Van Vuuren, Sagarika Jaisinghani

item.title: Malaysia Taps Career Diplomat as New US Ambassador Amid Tariffs
item.description: Malaysia has tapped a career diplomat as its new ambassador to the US, according to people familiar with the matter, as the Southeast Asian nation seeks tariff relief from Washington.
item.dc:creator: Ram Anand, Niki Koswanage, Faris Mokhtar

media:content.media:description: Shahrul Ikram Yaakob Photographer: Albin Lohr-Jones/Pacific Press/LightRocket/Getty Images

item.title: US ‘Bigger Bubble’ Shift May Ignite Stocks, Says BofA’s Hartnett
item.description: The latest turn by the Trump administration to favor tax cuts and lower tariffs has the potential to kick off another speculative frenzy in markets, according to Bank of America Corp. strategists.
item.dc:creator: Michael Msika

item.title: Eletrobras Is Said to Draw Chinese Firms for Eletronuclear Stake
item.description: Centrais Elétricas Brasileiras SA, the Brazilian power company known as Eletrobras, has drawn preliminary interest from Chinese state-owned enterprises for its stake in nuclear firm Eletronuclear, according to people with knowledge of the matter.
item.dc:creator: Pei Li, Dong Cao, Rachel Gamarski, Cristiane Lucchesi

media:content.media:description: The Electronuclear Angra 1 Nuclear Power Plant in Angra dos Reis, Rio de Janeiro state, Brazil, on Monday, March 27, 2023. The Brazilian Institute for the Environment and Renewable Natural Resources (Ibama) has fined Eletronuclear for an accident at the Angra 1 Nuclear Power Plant in September of last year in which the facility released water contaminated by radioactive material in to the bay of Angra dos Reis.

item.title: Dollar’s Weekly Gain Looks Like a Blip as Pressures Mount
item.description: The best week for the dollar in three months isn’t enough to reverse its broader declines as US trade and policy uncertainty weighs on sentiment.
item.dc:creator: Vassilis Karamanis

item.title: Shapoorji Closes $3.4 Billion Record India Private Debt Deal
item.description: Indian real estate and construction conglomerate Shapoorji Pallonji Group has completed a $3.4 billion financing in the country’s biggest ever private credit deal, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Saikat Das

media:content.media:description: The Odyssey residential project under construction, developed by Shapoorji Pallonji Group, in Mumbai, India, on Wednesday, May 14, 2025. Indian real estate and construction conglomerate Shapoorji Pallonji Group is aiming to sign a $3.4 billion private credit deal in coming hours that would be the country’s biggest ever, people familiar with the matter said. Photographer: Dhiraj Singh/Bloomberg

item.title: Inflation Dips Below 2% in Italy and Spain, Backing ECB Cut
item.description: Inflation in Italy and Spain eased to just below the European Central Bank’s 2% target, backing the case for interest rates to be lowered again next week.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Basteiro

media:content.media:description: Spain's consumer prices rose 1.9% from a year ago in May. Photographer: Angel Garcia/Bloomberg

item.title: Poland Election Closely Watched by EU
item.description: The presidential election runoff in Poland is deeply dividing the country, with families and streets split over who to vote for between Warsaw Mayor Rafal Trzaskowski and Karol Nawrocki. The election has huge implications for Poland's future, including its role in Europe, women's rights, national identity, and support for neighboring Ukraine, with the outcome affecting the country's relationship with the EU and NATO. Mart Prochwicz, European Council on Foreign Relations Warsaw Office Deputy Head speaks to Bloomberg as households head to vote on what is seen as a referendum on Poland's future. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Stock Bulls Face June Reckoning After May’s Meltup
item.description: Equity market is entering a historically weak period of the year
item.dc:creator: Jess Menton, Phil Serafino

item.title: India Yoga Guru’s Firm Faces Scrutiny Over Financial Deals
item.description: India’s government has asked Patanjali Ayurved Ltd., a traditional medicine company co-founded by celebrity yoga guru Baba Ramdev, to explain some transactions deemed suspicious, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Ruchi Bhatia

item.title: Adani, Emaar Said to Cease Talks on Indian Real Estate Unit Sale
item.description: Billionaire Gautam Adani’s real estate division has decided against buying the Indian unit of Dubai-based developer Emaar Group due to disagreements on valuation, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Baiju Kalesh, Sanjai P R, Anto Antony

media:content.media:description: The logo of Emaar Properties PJSC on skyscrapers on the city skyline in downtown Dubai, United Arab Emirates, on Friday, Sept. 16, 2022. Office rents in Dubai are rebounding for the first time in six years, rising faster than in New York or London as global banks and businesses expand into the financial hub known for its love of glitzy construction.

item.title: S&P 500’s Banner Month Faces Off With June’s Lackluster Record
item.description: A frenzied May rally has equity analysts bracing for an end to the run in what has historically been one of the weakest months for S&P 500 Index returns.
item.dc:creator: Jess Menton

item.title: Attock Cement Pakistan Is Said to Draw Cherat, Bestway Interest
item.description: Pharaon Investment Group Ltd.’s potential sale of Attock Cement Pakistan Ltd. is attracting initial interest from rivals including Cherat Cement Co. and Bestway Group, people with knowledge of the matter said.
item.dc:creator: Faseeh Mangi

media:content.media:description: A construction site in Karachi, Pakistan. Photographer: Asim Hafeez/Bloomberg

item.title: DBS Is Said to Shelve Plans for Asia Insurance Deal on Valuation
item.description: DBS Group Holdings Ltd. has shelved plans to form an insurance partnership in India and Taiwan after initial offers from prospective bidders didn’t match value expectations, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Manuel Baigorri, Elffie Chew

media:content.media:description: The DBS Group Holdings Ltd. logo on sail boats in Singapore, on Monday, Feb. 10, 2025. DBS shares jumped after the lender reported earnings that met expectations and unveiled a investor payout plan.

item.title: Oil Poised for Small Weekly Loss Ahead of OPEC+ Supply Decision
item.description: Oil was on track for a marginal weekly decline ahead of an OPEC+ meeting on output policy that’s expected to lead to another supply hike.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Chen, Alex Longley

media:content.media:description: Fuel and crude oil storage tanks at the Galp Energia SGPS SA Sines refinery plant in Sines, Portugal, on Tuesday, March 25, 2025. Galp expects its biofuels and green hydrogen projects located at the Sines refinery will be operating in mid-2026. Photographer: Goncalo Fonseca/Bloomberg

item.title: Hedge Funds Tout Japanese Tires, Hungarian Drugs at Sohn HK
item.description: Hedge funds pitched investment ideas ranging from a Japanese tiremaker to a Hungarian pharmaceutical company at the Sohn Hong Kong Investment Leaders Conference on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Bei Hu, Echo Wong, Lisa Du, David Ramli

item.title: UBS Loses Two More Senior Bankers in Asia Amid Ongoing Revamp
item.description: Two Hong Kong-based senior bankers have resigned from UBS Group AG, according to a company spokesperson, amid the bank’s ongoing revamp of its financing business following the takeover of Credit Suisse.
item.dc:creator: Apple Ka Ying Li, Megawati Wijaya

media:content.media:description: Signage for UBS Group AG at an office building in Hong Kong. Photographer: Bertha Wang/Bloomberg

item.title: Reform Chairman on Farage's Bid for UK Crypto Hub
item.description: Reform UK leader Nigel Farage attempted to woo younger British voters by announcing a Donald Trump-style foray into cryptocurrency policy at a Bitcoin conference in Las Vegas on Thursday. Reform Chairman Zia Yusuf discusses the plan on Bloomberg Television. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: ECB’s Panetta Suggests Inflation Is Almost Defeated in Euro Zone
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Fabio Panetta signaled that inflation is nearly fully tamed, while cautioning that further interest-rate cuts require finely balanced judgments.
item.dc:creator: Flavia Rotondi, Alessandra Migliaccio, Sonia Sirletti

item.title: Turkey’s Economy Cools at Start of Year Despite Rate Cuts
item.description: Turkey’s economy cooled in the first quarter as high interest rates continued to weigh on activity despite a trio of early cuts by the central bank.
item.dc:creator: Beril Akman

media:content.media:description: Shoppers at the Mahmutpasha market in Istanbul. Photographer: Kerem Uzel/Bloomberg

item.title: Wang Yi Urges Global Dialog as China Backs Hong Kong for Mediation Hub
item.description: China’s Foreign Minister Wang Yi urged countries to look beyond zero-sum thinking and resolve disputes through dialog, as he signed a convention to set up a global mediation organization in Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: Shirley Zhao

media:content.media:description: Wang Yi on May 30. Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg

item.title: European Stocks Set for Biggest Monthly Advance Since January
item.description: European stocks were set for the biggest monthly gain since January, as investors monitored the outlook for global trade.
item.dc:creator: Sagarika Jaisinghani

item.title: Japan Calls On Companies to Find Value Beyond Share Buybacks
item.description: Japan’s government called on corporate management to find better ways to use money than by just buying back shares, echoing some investors’ views that Japanese firms need to improve their growth strategies.
item.dc:creator: Yasutaka Tamura, Momoka Yokoyama

media:content.media:description: The Tokyo Stock Exchange (TSE) building, operated by Japan Exchange Group Inc. (JPX), in Tokyo, Japan, on Wednesday, April 9, 2025. Japanese stocks tumbled as concerns about US trade tariffs and wild swings on Wall Street sapped investor confidence, while the yen extended its rally.

item.title: Markets in Defensive Limbo Into Weekend: 3-Minute MLIV
item.description: Guy Johnson, Kriti Gupta and Mark Cudmore break down today's key themes for analysts and investors on "Bloomberg: The Opening Trade." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Krishna Memani on Wall Street's Very Expensive ‘Free Lunch’
item.description: Why international diversification has been a flop.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

media:content.media:description: Krishna Memani, chief investment officer of OppenheimerFunds Inc., speaks during a Bloomberg Television interview in New York, U.S., on Friday, Feb. 15, 2019. Memani expects OAS to bottom out around 100 basis points by year end.

item.title: Odd Lots: Krishna Memani on Diversification’s Struggle (Podcast)
item.description: We’re told over and over again that the one “free lunch” in investing is diversification, and that you can improve your returns over time simply by investing in a wider range of assets. This is textbook modern finance. And yet over the past several years this hasn’t been the case. An investor would have done great (with the occasional hiccups) just by investing in US stocks. What’s more, even within US stocks, investors should have concentrated on big tech stocks. Going long US tech has been ide
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

item.title: ‘Baby Shark’ Creator Pinkfong Applies for IPO in South Korea
item.description: The company behind “Baby Shark,” the most watched YouTube video of all time, will go public in South Korea.
item.dc:creator: Sangmi Cha

item.title: Credit Agricole Brings Back Floating Samurai Bonds After Decade
item.description: Credit Agricole SA is issuing floating-rate Samurai bonds for the first time in about a decade, as it draws strong demand from investors worried about rising Japanese government bond yields.
item.dc:creator: Takahiko Hyuga

media:content.media:description: Credit Agricole SA Photographer: Balint Porneczi/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Tariff Reprieve; Gaza Ceasefire Proposal | Horizons Middle East & Africa 05/30/2025
item.description: A federal appeals court has temporarily blocked a ruling that threatened to throw out the bulk of President Donald Trump's tariff agenda. Also on the show: Trump pushed Fed Chair Jerome Powell to cut rates at their first in-person meeting since his inauguration; the White House says a Gaza ceasefire proposal has been submitted to Hamas; defense ministers and senior military figures are in Singapore for the annual Shangri-La Dialogue; oil is set for its second weekly decline ahead of OPEC+ meeting; the African Development Bank has elected Sidi Ould Tah as its new president; the US is considering a deal with Rwanda to accept deportees; Google and the US Department of Justice are slated to offer closing arguments in an antitrust case. Guests include: Ozan Özkural, Tanto Capital Partners, Founder & Managing Partner; Livia Gallarati, Energy Aspects, Global Crude Lead. (Source: Bloomberg)
